title: CDC layoffs strike deeply at its ability to respond to the current public health emergencies
content: In just a few short weeks, the Trump administration has brought drastic changes to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and public health. Beginning with the removal of websites and key public health datasets in January 2025, the Trump administration has taken actions to dismantle established public health infrastructure as part of its second-term agenda.
contentSnippet: In just a few short weeks, the Trump administration has brought drastic changes to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and public health. Beginning with the removal of websites and key public health datasets in January 2025, the Trump administration has taken actions to dismantle established public health infrastructure as part of its second-term agenda.

title: More people are asking generative AI questions about their health. But the wrong answer can be risky
content: More people are turning to generative artificial intelligence (AI) to help them in their daily and professional lives. ChatGPT is one of the most well-known and widely available generative AI tools. It gives tailored, plausible answers to any question for free.
contentSnippet: More people are turning to generative artificial intelligence (AI) to help them in their daily and professional lives. ChatGPT is one of the most well-known and widely available generative AI tools. It gives tailored, plausible answers to any question for free.

title: Eating walnuts for breakfast may boost your brain function
content: Eating walnuts for breakfast could improve brain function throughout the day for young adults, a new study has shown.
contentSnippet: Eating walnuts for breakfast could improve brain function throughout the day for young adults, a new study has shown.

title: Fortifying bouillon could reduce malnutrition in West Africa
content: In September, the Nigerian government made an important change to its food fortification program to date—a set of standards outlining that voluntarily fortified bouillon cubes must contain minimum amounts of four micronutrients: iron, zinc, folic acid and vitamin B12. While some foods are already fortified in the country, the dehydrated seasoning blocks, consumed in virtually all Nigerian households, may prove to be the ideal vessel for some vitamins and minerals.
contentSnippet: In September, the Nigerian government made an important change to its food fortification program to date—a set of standards outlining that voluntarily fortified bouillon cubes must contain minimum amounts of four micronutrients: iron, zinc, folic acid and vitamin B12. While some foods are already fortified in the country, the dehydrated seasoning blocks, consumed in virtually all Nigerian households, may prove to be the ideal vessel for some vitamins and minerals.

title: About 740,000 global deaths from suicide occur annually—that's one death every 43 seconds
content: About 740,000 suicides are reported annually: that's one death on average every 43 seconds, one of the many disturbing findings in the latest and most comprehensive analysis published today in The Lancet Public Health.
contentSnippet: About 740,000 suicides are reported annually: that's one death on average every 43 seconds, one of the many disturbing findings in the latest and most comprehensive analysis published today in The Lancet Public Health.

title: Trump administration reverses plan to end free COVID test program
content: The Trump administration changed course on Tuesday, deciding to keep the government's free COVID test program running, just minutes before the website COVIDtests.gov was set to shut down.
contentSnippet: The Trump administration changed course on Tuesday, deciding to keep the government's free COVID test program running, just minutes before the website COVIDtests.gov was set to shut down.

title: Study shows smoking is tied to some unexplained strokes in young adults
content: Smoking, particularly heavy smoking, is linked to some unexplained strokes in younger adults, mainly in male individuals and in people ages 45 to 49, according to a study published in Neurology Open Access.
contentSnippet: Smoking, particularly heavy smoking, is linked to some unexplained strokes in younger adults, mainly in male individuals and in people ages 45 to 49, according to a study published in Neurology Open Access.

title: New study links dust storms to increased emergency department visits in the US Southwest
content: A new research study highlights the significant health risks associated with dust storms, revealing an increase in emergency department (ED) visits for respiratory and cardiovascular conditions, as well as motor vehicle accidents, in three Southwestern U.S. states. The study, which was led by National Jewish Health, was published this month in JAMA Network Open.
contentSnippet: A new research study highlights the significant health risks associated with dust storms, revealing an increase in emergency department (ED) visits for respiratory and cardiovascular conditions, as well as motor vehicle accidents, in three Southwestern U.S. states. The study, which was led by National Jewish Health, was published this month in JAMA Network Open.

title: Text message tool addresses 'time toxicity' for cancer patients
content: Cancer patients spend a lot of time on their care. Meeting with doctors and other members of their health care team, getting labs and other tests, picking up prescriptions, and undergoing treatment all takes time. So does getting to and from each appointment, sitting in the waiting room between each appointment, and so on.
contentSnippet: Cancer patients spend a lot of time on their care. Meeting with doctors and other members of their health care team, getting labs and other tests, picking up prescriptions, and undergoing treatment all takes time. So does getting to and from each appointment, sitting in the waiting room between each appointment, and so on.

title: Younger, health-conscious consumers are embracing organic, survey shows
content: A $70-billion market now, organic may be maturing, but younger consumers —including new parents and their babies—are eating it up. A survey released by the Organic Trade Association (OTA) finds that organic's benefits to personal health and nutrition are resonating deeply with Millennials and Gen Zer's, making them the most committed organic consumers of any generation.
contentSnippet: A $70-billion market now, organic may be maturing, but younger consumers —including new parents and their babies—are eating it up. A survey released by the Organic Trade Association (OTA) finds that organic's benefits to personal health and nutrition are resonating deeply with Millennials and Gen Zer's, making them the most committed organic consumers of any generation.

title: How medical treatments devised for war can quickly be implemented in US hospitals to save lives
content: For decades, military doctors faced a critical challenge: What's the best way to safely and effectively deliver oxygen to patients in remote combat zones, rural hospitals or disaster-stricken areas?
contentSnippet: For decades, military doctors faced a critical challenge: What's the best way to safely and effectively deliver oxygen to patients in remote combat zones, rural hospitals or disaster-stricken areas?

title: Increased death rates in the most deprived areas of cities in England and Scotland
content: Death rates in the most deprived areas of cities in England and Scotland have been increasing since the start of the last decade, widening inequalities between the richest and poorest in society.
contentSnippet: Death rates in the most deprived areas of cities in England and Scotland have been increasing since the start of the last decade, widening inequalities between the richest and poorest in society.

title: Lifestyle and environmental factors affect health and aging more than our genes, study finds
content: A study led by researchers from Oxford Population Health has shown that a range of environmental factors, including lifestyle (smoking and physical activity), and living conditions, have a greater impact on health and premature death than our genes.
contentSnippet: A study led by researchers from Oxford Population Health has shown that a range of environmental factors, including lifestyle (smoking and physical activity), and living conditions, have a greater impact on health and premature death than our genes.

title: What high triglycerides mean and why it matters to your heart
content: You may be familiar with high-density, or good cholesterol; low-density lipoproteins (LDL), or bad cholesterol; and their connections to heart health. But what about triglycerides? Often that word gets skimmed over when talking about cholesterol levels.
contentSnippet: You may be familiar with high-density, or good cholesterol; low-density lipoproteins (LDL), or bad cholesterol; and their connections to heart health. But what about triglycerides? Often that word gets skimmed over when talking about cholesterol levels.

title: We are no longer living longer, study shows
content: The rise in human life expectancy has slowed down across Europe since 2011, according to research from the University of East Anglia and partners.
contentSnippet: The rise in human life expectancy has slowed down across Europe since 2011, according to research from the University of East Anglia and partners.

title: Would the prohibition of menthol cigarettes cause more harm than good?
content: New research published in Health Economics indicates that a national prohibition of menthol cigarettes in the United States could increase the number of people who attempt to quit smoking but also support an illegal menthol cigarette market.
contentSnippet: New research published in Health Economics indicates that a national prohibition of menthol cigarettes in the United States could increase the number of people who attempt to quit smoking but also support an illegal menthol cigarette market.

title: Five things to know about fainting: The heart's role and when it may signal serious condition
content: You may have heard that people who feel faint should sit with their heads between their knees, but is that true? And how can you tell whether you or someone else who has fainted should go to the emergency department or perhaps even see a cardiologist? Elijah Behr, M.D., a cardiologist at Mayo Clinic Healthcare in London, explains five things it is important to know about fainting.
contentSnippet: You may have heard that people who feel faint should sit with their heads between their knees, but is that true? And how can you tell whether you or someone else who has fainted should go to the emergency department or perhaps even see a cardiologist? Elijah Behr, M.D., a cardiologist at Mayo Clinic Healthcare in London, explains five things it is important to know about fainting.

title: Paying attention to four health factors can help prevent new heart syndrome
content: About 90% of U.S. adults meet the criteria for a newly recognized syndrome that comes from a combination of heart disease, kidney disease, type 2 diabetes and obesity. This cluster of chronic health conditions is called cardiovascular-kidney-metabolic (CKM) syndrome. It can be prevented by paying attention to four health factors, according to scientific experts at the American Heart Association, a global force changing the future of health for all.
contentSnippet: About 90% of U.S. adults meet the criteria for a newly recognized syndrome that comes from a combination of heart disease, kidney disease, type 2 diabetes and obesity. This cluster of chronic health conditions is called cardiovascular-kidney-metabolic (CKM) syndrome. It can be prevented by paying attention to four health factors, according to scientific experts at the American Heart Association, a global force changing the future of health for all.

title: Surfer's ear: The condition that might leave wild swimmers and surfers with hearing loss
content: Cold water swimming, paddleboarding and surfing are all popular pastimes— with millions of people in the UK regularly participating in at least one type of outdoor watersport each year.
contentSnippet: Cold water swimming, paddleboarding and surfing are all popular pastimes— with millions of people in the UK regularly participating in at least one type of outdoor watersport each year.

title: Trans people affirmed their gender without medical help in medieval Europe
content: Restrictions on medical care for transgender youth assume that without the ability to medically transition, trans people will vanish.
contentSnippet: Restrictions on medical care for transgender youth assume that without the ability to medically transition, trans people will vanish.

title: Tweets and AI models reveal heat stroke risks in urban areas
content: Heat stroke poses a significant health risk, especially during extreme temperature conditions. As global temperatures rise due to climate change, the frequency and severity of heat waves have increased, putting vulnerable populations at greater risk.
contentSnippet: Heat stroke poses a significant health risk, especially during extreme temperature conditions. As global temperatures rise due to climate change, the frequency and severity of heat waves have increased, putting vulnerable populations at greater risk.

title: Scientists decode diet from stool DNA, no questions asked
content: Scientists have developed a breakthrough method to track diet using stool metagenomic data.
contentSnippet: Scientists have developed a breakthrough method to track diet using stool metagenomic data.

title: Swimming in some lakes can lead to infection with Legionella, warn scientists
content: Swimming in some lakes with still water can lead to infection with Legionella, bacteria that can cause pneumonia, and people who engage in open water swimming should be aware of this risk, say the authors of a practice article published in the Canadian Medical Association Journal.
contentSnippet: Swimming in some lakes with still water can lead to infection with Legionella, bacteria that can cause pneumonia, and people who engage in open water swimming should be aware of this risk, say the authors of a practice article published in the Canadian Medical Association Journal.

title: Ventilation fans can significantly lower the risk of inhaling bacteria particles after toilet flushing
content: Bioaerosol emissions during toilet flushing are an often-overlooked source of potential health risks in shared public facilities. A new study published in Risk Analysis found that bioaerosol concentrations of two bacteria—Escherichia coli (E. coli) and Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus)—exceeded acceptable levels established by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) after toilet flushing. Inhaling these biological particles can produce symptoms like abdominal cramps, nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting.
contentSnippet: Bioaerosol emissions during toilet flushing are an often-overlooked source of potential health risks in shared public facilities. A new study published in Risk Analysis found that bioaerosol concentrations of two bacteria—Escherichia coli (E. coli) and Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus)—exceeded acceptable levels established by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) after toilet flushing. Inhaling these biological particles can produce symptoms like abdominal cramps, nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting.

title: Colorado has 'very high' flu activity, but not as bad as the rest of the country
content: The flu is widespread in Colorado, but the virus hasn't hit the state nearly as hard as some others.
contentSnippet: The flu is widespread in Colorado, but the virus hasn't hit the state nearly as hard as some others.
